xxl.binarySearchTrees
Class BinarySearchTree

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.binarySearchTrees.BinarySearchTree
Direct Known Subclasses:
AVLTree, BBTree, RedBlackTree
public class BinarySearchTree
extends Object

BinarySearchTree is a generic implementation of the funcionality of binary search trees. The implementation uses some ideas that are described in: "Introduction to Algorithms", MIT Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, by Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest.

Trees constructed using this class are not implicitly balanced. For balanced trees consider the classes AVLTree and RedBlackTree.

See Also:
AVLTree, RedBlackTree

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
Returns a Factory-Method Function (Function x Function -> BinarySearchTree) that constructs new BinarySearchTrees.

root

protected BinarySearchTree.Node root
Root of the tree.

size

protected int size
Size of the tree (number of Nodes).

fixAggregate

protected Function fixAggregate
Updates aggregate-information of a node, i.e. the invariant for that node is recomputed. This function is called with 1 argument: the node. The return-type is boolean: is the aggregate-operation complete or does the parent has to be updated (only during insertion).

fixRotation

protected Function fixRotation
Updates rotation-information of a node. This function is called with 1 argument: the node
Constructor Detail

BinarySearchTree

public BinarySearchTree(Function fixAggregate,
                        Function fixRotation)
Creates a BinarySearchTree.
Parameters:
fixAggregate - Function that is called when an aggregate information in the tree might be outdated.
fixRotation - Function that is called when a rotation has occured and rotation information in a node has to become fixed.
Method Detail

newNode

public BinarySearchTree.Node newNode(Object object,
                                     BinarySearchTree.Node parent)
Creates and initializes a new node of the tree. The Node is inserted into the tree only if the parent is set correctly.
Parameters:
object - The Object that is contained in the Node.
parent - The parent Node of the Node that becomes created.
Returns:
Node - new Node that contains the Object object.

clear

public void clear()
Deletes all elements of the tree. After this operation the tree is empty.

init

public void init(Object object)
Initialized the tree with exactly one Node that contains the specified Object. Caution: if the tree is not empty, the previously contained Nodes are removed. After performing this operation the number of Nodes in the tree is exactly 1.
Parameters:
object - The object that is inserted into the only Node of the tree (root).

root

public BinarySearchTree.Node root()
Returns root of the tree.
Returns:
Node - the root of the tree.

size

public int size()
Returns the size of the tree (number of Nodes)
Returns:
int - size of the tree

first

public BinarySearchTree.Node first()
Returns the first Node due to the tree comparator.
Returns:
Node - the first Node of the tree.

last

public BinarySearchTree.Node last()
Returns the last Node due to the tree comparator.
Returns:
Node - the last Node of the tree.

get

public BinarySearchTree.Node get(Comparator chooseSubtree,
                                 Object[] object,
                                 int[] result)
Exactmatch query. Locates an Object in the tree.
Parameters:
chooseSubtree - Comparator that is used to find the requested Object.
object - Object[] that contains the Object.
result - int[] that contains a return value (see "Returns").
Returns:
Node that contains the Object or the Node where the search had to be terminated (result[0] is set to 0 if the Object was found, <0 if Object is left of that Node, >0 if greater than the Node)

insert

public BinarySearchTree.Node insert(Comparator chooseSubtree,
                                    Object[] object)
Inserts an Object into the tree.
Parameters:
chooseSubtree - Comparator that is used to locate the place where the Object becomes inserted.
object - Object[] that contains the Object.
Returns:
null if the Tree did not contain the Object otherwise the Node that already contains the Object (if it is already in the tree). In the latter case there are no changes in the tree.

remove

public BinarySearchTree.Node remove(Comparator chooseSubtree,
                                    Object[] object,
                                    int nextIndex)
Search the object and remove it from the tree.
Parameters:
chooseSubtree - Comparator that is used to find the Object.
object - Object[] that contains the Object.
nextIndex -  
Returns:
null if the Tree did not contain the Object otherwise the Node that has contained the Object before the remove-Operation.

iterator

public Iterator iterator()
Returns an inorder forward (left to right) iterator of the objects of this tree.
Returns:
Iterator - inorder forward iterator.

iterator

public Iterator iterator(boolean forwards)
Returns an inorder iterator of the objects of this tree.
Parameters:
forwards - true: forward (left to right) otherwise backwards(right to left).
Returns:
Iterator - specified inorder iterator.

levelOrderIterator

public Iterator levelOrderIterator()
Returns a level order iterator of the objects of this tree.
Returns:
Iterator - level order iterator.

rangeQuery

public Iterator rangeQuery(Comparator chooseSubtree,
                           Object[] minkey,
                           Object[] maxkey,
                           boolean forwards)
Returns an inorder iterator that contains the Objects that lie between minkey and maxkey (range query).
Parameters:
chooseSubtree - The comparator used to choose the right subtree.
minkey - defines the left border.
maxkey - defines the right border.
forwards - specifies the order the elements are returned.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
                 throws Exception
Use case: Storing Intervals In this Example we use the aggregate Function to compute the maximum of the right margins of the intervals in the child nodes. The aggregate Function is called every time the tree changes in such a manner that an aggregate has to become updated.
